citation.article-title: Mycobacterium senuense sp. nov., a slowly growing, non-chromogenic species closely related to the Mycobacterium terrae complex.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Mycobacterium senuense sp. nov.

Mycobacterium senuense (se.nu.en′se. N.L. neut. adj. senuense arbitrary name formed from the initial letters of Seoul National University, the organization that carried out the taxonomic investigation of the type strain).
Cells are generally rod-shaped and frequently bent.
Spores and filaments are not present.
On Middlebrook 7H10 medium, mature growth develops in 4 weeks at 25 and 37 °C.
Microcolonies develop in 3 weeks at the same temperature.
However, 5 weeks or more is required to form mature colonies on LJ medium.
Colonies grown on Middlebrook 7H10 agar are usually rough and produce no pigmentation under both dark and photoinduction conditions.
Cells on LJ medium grow in a film-like manner and produce no pigmentation.
No growth is observed on MacConkey agar or on culture medium containing 5 % NaCl or 5 mg EMB ml−1.
The type strain is susceptible to PNB at 500 mg ml−1 but tolerant of TCH at 10 mg ml−1.
Negative for urease activity, arylsulfatase and niacin accumulation and positive for Tween 80 hydrolysis, nitrate reductase, heat-stable catalase, pyrazinamidase and tellurite reductase.
HPLC analysis shows a unique mycolic acid profile.
Genetically, the organism has unique Mycobacterium sequences for the 16S rRNA, hsp65 and rpoB genes.

Phylogenetic analysis using 16S rRNA gene sequences shows that the species belongs to the slowly growing mycobacteria and is closely related to members of the M. terrae complex, i.e. M. terrae, M. nonchromogenicum, M. arupense and M. hiberniae.
The type strain is 05-832T (=DSM 44999T =KCTC 19147T), isolated from human sputum samples in Seoul, Korea.
